The term is spelled moire -with a French accent over the e. It refers to the concentric ring-like
effect when certain patterns (in particular those of a linear nature) are displayed on a computer
monitor, for instance.  Although I am by no means a desktop publishing expert, I would question
your need to scan at such a high resolution.  What will be the final format upon which your
objects are shown?  Website, print-out, computer screen?  Many scanners have high settings, but
actually interpolate, or fill in the gaps, to create a false 'high resolution'. Perhaps you could
scan at 600 or so and capture enough information. 
Also, I have found sometimes, that after you scan, you may see a moire pattern on the photoshop
window, but if you enlarge or reduce the image by a step, the pattern goes away.  It's all about
trying to display a continuous image in a pixellated manner.
Regards,
Doug Sanders
--- Gordon Robson <robsongo@...> wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> I'm looking for a little free advice on scanning. I am using a 
> Canoscan9900F, which is a very good scanner. I begin my scans through 
> Photoshop 7.0 into ScanGear CS. I have been using very high dpis of 
> 1600 and 800 with the weak morei (spelling?) turned on and the sharp 
> turned off. I am still getting nasty looking morei in my scans of 
> oshigata for this summer's lecture. Any ideas on what I need to do to 
> improve my scans?
> 
> Gordon
> 
> 
>
